The site-symmetry induced representations of layer
groups on the Bilbao Crystallographic Server
Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Institute of Applied Geosciences, Karlsruhe, Germany,
Materia Condensada, Facultad de Ciencia y Tecnologı
of Chemistry, Saint Petersburg State University, Saint Petersburg, Russian Federation,
Department of Physics Engineering, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey. *Correspondence
The section of the Bilbao Crystallographic Server (http://www.cryst.ehu.es)
dedicated to subperiodic groups includes a new tool called
study of materials with layer and multilayer symmetry. This new program, based
on the site-symmetry approach, establishes the symmetry relations between
localized and extended crystal states using representations of layer groups. The
efﬁciency and utility of the program
examples, which include the analysis of phonon symmetry in Aurivillius
compounds and in van der Waals layered crystals MoS
The interest in layered and multilayered materials such as
with Me = Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Ti, V, Zr, Hf and
2017), is constantly growing owing to their interesting prop-
erties and possible technological applications. The symmetry
of single monolayers can be described by the ‘diperiodic’ or
translations. There are 80 layer groups which, together with
the seven frieze groups (two-dimensional groups with one-
dimensional translations) and the 75 rod groups (three-
constitute the ‘subperiodic groups’. The crystallographic data
for subperiodic groups are compiled in
) and also offered online by the Bilbao
While space groups and their representations describe the
symmetry of the bulk electron and phonon states, the layer
groups are essential for the description of the electronic
structure and the surface states of crystals. Depending on the
interaction between the layer and the bulk, materials with
layer symmetry can be classiﬁed into ﬁve different types: (i)
pure layered systems like free-standing ﬁlms, with graphene
monolayers as a notable example of such ﬁlms; (ii) single
layers in layered crystals which, owing to a weak van der Waals
interlayer interaction, can be separated from the bulk; (iii)
artiﬁcial nanolayers grown on substrates or between two bulk
materials where the interaction between the nanolayer and
